header.title: LIBER CCXXXI: Liber Arcanorum Atu Tahuti Qvas Vidit Asar in Amenti svb Figvrâ CCXXXI, Liber Carcerorvm Qliphoth Cvm Suis Geniis Addentvr Sigilla Et Nomina Eorvm

central_thesis: Liber CCXXXI presents a symbolic, Qabalistic, and Thelemic cosmology describing the 22 paths of the Tree of Life (the 'Atu of Tahuti') and their corresponding 'Domarum Mercurii' (positive aspects) and 'Carcerorum Qliphoth' (shadow/demonic aspects). It provides a framework for understanding the universe's magical structure and a practical guide for engaging with the entities associated with these paths through their unique sigils and names, ultimately contributing to the process of initiatory understanding and mastery.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the dual nature of the 22 Arcana (Arcana of Tahuti and Prisons of the Qliphoth) and identifies the text as a Class A publication of the A∴A∴, establishing its Thelemic and Qabalistic context through the use of the A∴A∴ sigil and grade attribution (Adeptus Exemptus).

A mystical, allegorical narrative in 21 numbered paragraphs (plus an 'o' paragraph) detailing a cosmic and initiatory drama. It employs Egyptian deities (e.g., Asar, Asi, Tahuti, Nuit, Hadit, Ra-Hoor-Khuit) and Qabalistic concepts (e.g., Amennti, Sphinx, Pyramid), providing the philosophical and mythological underpinnings for the magical system and describing the unfolding of the universe and the path of the adept towards complete initiation.

This crucial practical section presents two tables of 22 unique visual sigils each: one for the 'Genii' of the 'Domarum Mercurii' (Houses of Mercury, representing positive aspects of the paths) and another for the 'Genii' of the 'Carcerorum Qliphoth' (Prisons of the Qliphoth, representing shadow/demonic aspects). These sigils serve as direct magical tools for focusing intent and establishing contact with the respective entities.

This section lists the 22 transliterated names of the Genii for both the 'Scales of the Serpent' (the paths themselves) and the 'Qliphoth'. These names, often a blend of Hebrew, Coptic, and Greek elements, are presented alongside their common Qabalistic counterparts (e.g., Amprodias, Baratchial) and are intended for use in conjunction with their sigils for practical magical work.

Provides critical contextual information, including a technical note on Coptic letter attributions (relevant for Qabalistic gematria), diary entries by Aleister Crowley detailing the text's creation around December 1907 (explicitly linking the sigils to the Atu of Tahuti), and a personal caution from Crowley regarding the 'unpleasant influence' of the Qliphothic sigils. It also situates Liber CCXXXI within Crowley's broader Class A corpus.

key_concepts.definition: Refers to the 22 Major Arcana of the Tarot, understood as representations of universal forces, archetypes, or paths on the Hermetic Tree of Life. Tahuti is the Egyptian deity Thoth, associated with knowledge, magic, and hieroglyphs.
'Houses of Mercury' - the positive, archetypal, or 'good' aspects of the 22 paths/Arcana, representing forces of spiritual growth, order, and manifestation in the manifested universe.

'Prisons of the Qliphoth' - the inverse, shadow, or demonic aspects corresponding to the 22 paths. The Qliphoth are often conceived as 'shells' or 'husks' of fallen or unbalanced Sephiroth, representing chaotic, destructive, or imbalanced forces, crucial for the adept to understand and confront.
Specific spirits, intelligences, or daemons associated with each of the 22 paths and their Qliphothic counterparts. The text provides their unique sigils and names for direct magical interaction.

The unique seals or glyphs provided for each of the 22 Genii. These are visual representations used in ritual to establish a magical link and channel the influence of the corresponding entity or force.

The magical order founded by Aleister Crowley, of which this text is a foundational 'Class A' document. It denotes a rigorous system of magical and mystical attainment and a specific hierarchical structure.

The overarching theme and goal, described allegorically in the narrative. It signifies a process of spiritual unfolding, understanding, and transformation, leading to a complete awareness and mastery of cosmic forces, including both the positive and Qliphothic aspects.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in Liber CCXXXI involves working with the 22 'Genii' associated with the paths of the Tree of Life, conceptualized as both 'Domarum Mercurii' (positive archetypal forces) and 'Carcerorum Qliphoth' (shadow or adverse forces). The text provides the specific sigils and transliterated names for these Genii. The allegorical narrative offers a philosophical and mythological framework, aligning this operative magic within a Thelemic initiatory context, aiming for a holistic understanding and mastery of cosmic forces, and ultimately, the adept's own spiritual evolution.
tools: The 22 Sigils of the Domarum Mercurii Genii (visual aids for focus and connection)
The 22 Sigils of the Carcerorum Qliphoth Genii (visual aids for focus and connection)
The 22 Names of the Genii for both aspects (transliterated for vibratory utterance and magical calling)
A comprehensive understanding of Hermetic Qabalah, including the Tree of Life, its 22 paths, and their Tarot correspondences (the 'Atu of Tahuti')
General ritual implements common in ceremonial magic (e.g., consecrated wand, sword, cup, pentacle, lamp, censer, altar, protective circle and triangle of art).
rituals: Invocation of the 'Domarum Mercurii Genii': Rituals designed to call forth and integrate the positive, ordered archetypal forces corresponding to the 22 paths. This would involve meditation upon the narrative, concentration on the specific sigil, and vibratory recitation of the corresponding name to align the practitioner with that particular cosmic current.

Evocation or Engagement with the 'Carcerorum Qliphoth Genii': Rituals aimed at confronting, understanding, and potentially binding or commanding the shadow or adverse forces of the Qliphoth. These would likely be more advanced and cautious ceremonies, utilizing the sigils and names to establish controlled contact, understand their nature, and transmute their energy for initiatory growth, as per Grimoire traditions modified for a Qabalistic context.

Qabalistic Pathworking: The sigils and names serve as focal points for journeying mentally or astrally along the 22 paths of the Tree of Life, exploring both the orderly and chaotic aspects of each path.

relevant_quotes.text: LIBER ARCANORVM τῶν ATV τοῦ TAHUTI QVAS VIDIT ASAR IN AMENTI SVB FIGVRÂ CCXXXI LIBER CARCERORVM τῶν QLIPHOTH CVM SUIS GENIIS ADDENTVR SIGILLA ET NOMINA EORVM
(This book is true up to the grade of Adeptus Exemptus. V.V.V.V.V. 8º, 3º.)
I think the Sigilla 22 have a very unpleasant influence.
Also Asar was hidden in Amennti; and the Lords of Time swept over him with the sickle of death.
Then also the Pyramid was builded so that the Initiation might be complete.

critical_analysis.relevance: Liber CCXXXI is a cornerstone text in Thelemic Qabalah and occultism. It systematically maps the 22 paths of the Tree of Life (corresponding to the Tarot Major Arcana or 'Atu of Tahuti') to both their positive ('Domarum Mercurii') and Qliphothic ('Carcerorum Qliphoth') aspects. By providing concrete magical tools—specifically the sigils and names of the associated 'Genii' for both sides—it offers a unique operative manual within a Qabalistic framework. This dualistic approach is crucial for a comprehensive understanding of consciousness and the cosmos, facilitating the integration of shadow aspects and a complete initiatory path. Its contribution lies in expanding Grimoire traditions into a highly structured Hermetic Qabalistic system, essential for Thelemic magical practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of advanced practitioners of Thelema, Hermetic Qabalah, and ceremonial magic, particularly those within or aspiring to the higher grades of the A∴A∴. It is not an introductory text, assuming a deep pre-existing understanding of Qabalistic principles, Tarot, and ritual magic. Magicians engaged in Qliphothic exploration, shadow integration, or complex planetary and elemental evocations would find this text invaluable, though Crowley's personal note serves as a caution regarding the potent and potentially perilous nature of working with these forces.
